content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player, I would consider the long-term strategy for this repeated game to maximize my earnings over the 75 rounds. If we both consistently pick the same option (either R or B), we will each earn 40$ or 20$ respectively in every other round. But if one player occasionally switches their choice, they can potentially gain an advantage by receiving 45$ in the rounds where their opponent chooses the same as before and still earn 40$ when they switch, while their opponent only earns 0$.

To minimize the chances of losing out on earnings due to my opponent's potential strategic switching, I would opt for a mixed strategy: picking R and B approximately equally often. This way, even if my opponent occasionally switches their choice, I can still expect to earn a reasonable payoff in most rounds since my strategy is unpredictable.

Given that the game consists of 75 rounds, it may seem tempting to lean towards choosing one option more frequently, but maintaining a balanced mix of choices could potentially yield better long-term results. In this scenario, my choice would be {R} or {B} with roughly equal probability, depending on the specifics of how I implement the mixed strategy.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 20$. Your opponent's payoff is 20$. Please play the next round.

In this round, since both my opponent and I chose B in the previous round, our payoff remains at 20$ each. Now it's time to decide on our choices for the following round.

As a human player, I will again consider my long-term strategy, aiming to maximize my earnings over the remaining 74 rounds. At this point, having both chosen B in the previous round, my opponent may anticipate that I might switch to R in the next round. If they suspect this, they could choose R themselves to take advantage of the situation and earn 45$.

To counteract this possibility, I will continue with a mixed strategy, choosing R or B approximately equally often. This way, my opponent will find it difficult to predict my future choices, and I can potentially gain an edge by occasionally switching my choice when they expect me to switch and vice versa.

With that in mind, for the next round, I'll choose {R}. It is worth noting that my decision is not based solely on the previous round's outcome but rather a long-term perspective of maximizing earnings over multiple rounds while maintaining an unpredictable strategy.
